newsitem.title: CANADA: Toronto stocks finish lower, hit by U.S. nosedive.
newsitem.headline: Toronto stocks finish lower, hit by U.S. nosedive.

text.p: Toronto stocks lost more ground in afternoon dealings on Thursday, but emerged from a rough session less wounded than their U.S. counterparts which were badly beaten by strong U.S. economic data.
"I think we held in exceptionally well in terms of the bond market. (Equities) were not that bad either," said independent strategist Bill Ram.

"We held in well considering the long weekend is coming up, considering the stronger-than-expected (U.S.) figures and considering that some economists are saying that there is an increased possibility that the Fed will raise interest rates."

The TSE 300 Composite Index dropped 21.26 points to 5162.83 in turnover of 85.9 million shares worth C$970.96 million. Declining shares outweighed advances 461 to 419, with 286 issues holding their ground.

U.S. bonds suffered when the second quarter gross domestic product increase was revised up to 4.8 percent from 4.2 percent. This exceeded expectations and marked the largest rise since a 4.9 percent climb in the second quarter of 1994.
The Dow Jones Industrial Index finished 64.73 points lower at 5647.65.
Sources within Richardson Greenshields of Canada Ltd. said that it will be bought by Royal Bank of Canada brokerage arm RBC Dominion Securities for roughly C$480 million ($351 million).
Rumors of a deal prompted activity in the shares of the large independent brokerages, First Marathon and Midland Walwyn Inc.
Circuit board manufacturer Circo Craft Co. received an C$11 ($8.05) per share offer from a U.S. investment firm.
The company is the subject of a hostile C$9.50 ($6.95) a share bid from C-MAC Industries. Circo Craft rose 0.65 to 10.90 in relatively active trade.
